propositions.text: Mrs. McGillycuddy boards a train at Paddington Station.
She is described as short and stout, burdened with Christmas shopping.
Her porter is tall and moves with a measured stride.
The train is the 4:54 PM service to Braighton.
It stops at various stations including Michester, Wiveton, and Chardmouth.
Mrs. McGillycuddy is shown to her first-class carriage.
The porter is disappointed with her tip, deeming it too small for a first-class passenger.
The train departs, and Mrs. McGillycuddy falls asleep.
She wakes after 35 minutes feeling refreshed.
During the journey, another train passes by on a parallel track.
Mrs. McGillycuddy witnesses a murder in a carriage of the passing train.
She sees a man strangling a woman.
The woman's eyes bulge and her face becomes purple.
Mrs. McGillycuddy alerts a ticket collector about the murder.
The ticket collector is skeptical and suggests she might have been dreaming.
He points to a sensational novel she was reading, showing a similar scene.
She reaches Braighton and sends a note to the stationmaster.
She arrives at her destination, St. Mary's Mead.
She informs her hostess, Jane Marple, that she has witnessed a murder.
Miss Marple listens to Mrs. McGillycuddy's account.
She advises her to rest and discuss the matter after dinner.
Miss Marple offers chamomile tea instead of coffee.
Miss Marple validates Mrs. McGillycuddy's experience, suggesting it's unusual but not impossible.
She recounts a personal experience of observing a train with clear details of passengers.
Mrs. McGillycuddy describes the victim as young, possibly between 30 and 35, with fair hair and wearing a light-colored fur coat.
The perpetrator is described as tall with brown hair, wearing a thick coat.
Miss Marple predicts that news of the murder will appear in the morning papers.
The morning papers do not report the murder.
Miss Marple and Mrs. McGillycuddy visit the police station to report the incident to Inspector Conant.
Inspector Conant is polite but skeptical, suggesting Mrs. McGillycuddy might have misidentified the situation.
He promises to investigate.
Miss Marple discusses potential scenarios with Inspector Conant.
She considers how the body might have been disposed of.
Inspector Conant reports that the investigation yielded no results.
No body was found, no hospital treated such a woman, and no one noticed any unusual events on the train.
Mrs. McGillycuddy insists it was a murder.
Miss Marple suggests that they themselves might need to investigate further.
She proposes they travel back to Braighton on the same train.
Miss Marple begins to formulate a plan, leveraging her contacts and knowledge.
She contacts her grandnephew, David West, for train schedules and information.
She also enlists the help of Leonard, who has extensive map knowledge.
Miss Marple and Mrs. McGillycuddy take the 4:54 PM train to Braighton again.
They do not witness a parallel train this time.
Miss Marple makes detailed observations about the train journey and the location of the turn.
She realizes the significance of the train's speed, deceleration, and the sharp turn.
Miss Marple conceives a new line of inquiry.
She writes to Miss Florence Hill in Brayton for local information.
Miss Marple investigates maps and local records of Braighton.
She realizes she needs assistance for physical investigation, which she cannot undertake herself due to her age and frailty.
She decides to enlist the help of Lucy Eyelesbrough, a highly capable and practical woman.

concepts.name: Mrs. McGillycuddy
concepts.context: The primary witness to the murder, a stout, middle-aged woman laden with Christmas shopping.

concepts.name: Train
concepts.context: The mode of transport and the scene of the murder.

concepts.name: Murder
concepts.context: The central event witnessed by Mrs. McGillycuddy.

concepts.name: Miss Marple
concepts.context: The astute elderly lady who investigates the crime.

concepts.name: Braighton
concepts.context: A key station on the train route where the murder is theorized to have occurred and where Miss Marple investigates.

concepts.name: Station
concepts.context: Locations where passengers board, alight, and where initial reports are made.

concepts.name: Ticket collector
concepts.context: An official who dismisses Mrs. McGillycuddy's initial report.

concepts.name: Inspector Conant
concepts.context: The police officer who investigates the case initially and finds no evidence.

concepts.name: Body
concepts.context: The absence of the victim's body is a key mystery.

concepts.name: Investigation
concepts.context: The process of seeking to understand and solve the murder.

concepts.name: Woman
concepts.context: Refers to both the victim and Mrs. McGillycuddy, and other female characters.

concepts.name: Man
concepts.context: Refers to the perpetrator and other male characters.

concepts.name: Carriage
concepts.context: The compartment on the train where events unfold.

concepts.name: Evidence
concepts.context: The lack of tangible proof complicates the investigation.

concepts.name: Map
concepts.context: Used by Miss Marple to understand the train route and geography.

concepts.name: Lucy Eyelesbrough
concepts.context: A capable individual enlisted by Miss Marple to assist with the investigation.

concepts.name: Christmas
concepts.context: The time of year in which the story takes place, impacting travel and social events.

hierarchy.structure: The document is structured into four sections. Section 1 describes the initial events leading to the witnessing of the murder and the immediate aftermath. Section 2 details the early stages of investigation and the lack of official progress. Section 3 explores the growing conviction of the protagonists and Miss Marple's strategic planning. Section 4 focuses on Miss Marple's methodical approach to gathering information and enlisting help, leading towards a potential resolution.
